In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can define a function `wrap_string` that takes a `String` as input and wraps it at a specified `text_width` (defaulting to 10 characters per line). The function will return a vector of strings, where each element is a line from the original string wrapped according to the specified width.

Here's how you can define the function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = Vector{String}()
    current_line = ""
    for word in split(text)
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = ""
        end
        current_line *= " " * word
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)
    return lines
end
```

This function uses `split` to break the text into words and then iterates over them. It appends each word to a running line string until the length of the line exceeds `text_width`. When this happens, it adds the current line to the result vector and starts a new line. After processing all the words, it pushes the final line (if any) to the result vector.

Here's an example of how you can use the function:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! This is a very long sentence that should be wrapped into multiple lines.")
2-element Vector{String}:
 "Hello there! This is a very long sentence that should be wrapped into multiple lines."
 ""
```

In this example, the text width is set to 10 by default, and since the entire input string fits within 10 characters per line, it's returned as a single line with an empty second line.

If you want to wrap the text at a different width, you can specify it like so:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! This is a very long sentence that should be wrapped into multiple lines."; text_width=50)
2-element Vector{String}:
 "Hello there! This is a very long sentence that should be wrapped into multiple lines."
 ""
```

In this case, since the `text_width` is increased to 50, the entire string fits on one line without needing to wrap it.
